revised_title: Attachment Mechanisms of Aquatic Hyphomycetes: A Study on Eight Species
tldr: This study examines the attachment strength of conidia from eight species of aquatic Hyphomycetes, including Anguillospora crassa, Articulospora tetracladia, and Dimorphospora foliicola. The research shows that conidium morphology, particularly the number of contact points, affects initial attachment. The formation of appressoria significantly increases the strength of attachment at higher shear stresses. The findings contribute to understanding the colonization process of aquatic fungi in turbulent environments.
